message_1:
Consider a telecommunication company that needs to connect 6 cities with optical fibers. The cost of connecting each pair of cities is given in the following table:

| Cities | City A | City B | City C | City D | City E | City F |
|--------|--------|--------|--------|--------|--------|--------|
| City A | -      | 10     | 15     | 25     | -      | -      |
| City B | 10     | -      | 20     | -      | -      | -      |
| City C | 15     | 20     | -      | 30     | 20     | -      |
| City D | 25     | -      | 30     | -      | 15     | 20     |
| City E | -      | -      | 20     | 15     | -      | 10     |
| City F | -      | -      | -      | 20     | 10     | -      |

The company wants to connect all cities with the minimum possible cost. Formulate this as an optimization problem and find the minimum cost of connecting these cities.
message_2:
This problem can be formulated as a Minimum Spanning Tree (MST) problem. The objective is to find a tree that connects all cities (vertices) with the minimum possible cost (sum of edge weights).

We can use Kruskal's algorithm to find the MST:

1. Sort all the edges in the graph in increasing order of their weights.
2. Start with an empty graph to build the MST.
3. Add the edges to the MST in the sorted order, making sure that adding the edge does not form a cycle in the MST.
4. Repeat step 3 until all cities are connected.

Sorted edges with their weights:
(AB, 10), (EF, 10), (DE, 15), (AC, 15), (CE, 20), (DF, 20), (BC, 20), (CD, 30)

Now, let's build the MST:

1. Add edge (AB, 10) to the MST.
2. Add edge (EF, 10) to the MST.
3. Add edge (DE, 15) to the MST.
4. Add edge (AC, 15) to the MST.
5. Adding edge (CE, 20) would form a cycle, so skip it.
6. Add edge (DF, 20) to the MST.
7. All cities are now connected.

The MST has the following edges: (AB, 10), (EF, 10), (DE, 15), (AC, 15), (DF, 20)

The minimum cost of connecting these cities is the sum of the edge weights in the MST: 10 + 10 + 15 + 15 + 20 = 70.
